But there is something leaden at her heart
(Pray God it be not mortal) that even keeps her
From conversation with herself.
O whither will ye me cross affections pull me?
Fortune, Fate, and you whose powers direct our actions,
And dwell within us: you that are Angels
Guiding to virtue, wherefore have you given
So strong a hand to evil? wherefore suffered
A Temple of your own, you Deities
Where your fair selves dwelt only, and your goodness
Thus to be soiled with sin?
Heaven bless us all.
From whence comes this distemper? speak my fair one.
And have you none, love and obedience,
You ever faithful Servants to employ
In this strange story of impiety,
But me a Mother, Must I be your strumpet?
To lay black treason upon and in him,
In whom all sweetness was: in whom my love
Was proved, to have a being, in whom Justice,
And all the gods for our imaginations
Can work into a man, were more than vertues,
Ambition down to Hell, where thou wert fostered
Thou hast poisoned the best soul, the purest, whitest,
And merest innocentest itself that ever
Men's greedy hopes gave life to.
This is still stranger: lay this treason,
Open to my correction.
O what a combat duty and affection
Breeds in my blood.
If thou concealest him may
Beside my death the curses of the Country,
Troubles of conscience, and a wretched end,
Bring thee unto a poor forgotten grave.
My being: for another tongue to tell it,
Cease, a mother! some good man that dares
Speak for his King and Country: I am full
Of too much woman's pity: yet o Heaven,
Since it concerns the safety of my sovereign
Let it not be a cruelty in me
Nor draw a Mothers name in question,
Amongst unborn people, to give up that man:
To law and Justice that unrighteously
Has sought his fathers death: be deaf, be deaf Sir,
Your Son is the Offender, Now have you all,
Would I might never speak again.
My Son? Heaven help me.
No more I thought it: and since
His life is grown so dangerous: Let them that
Gave him, take him: He shall die,
And with him all my fears.
O use your mercy: you have a brave subject
To bestow it on, I will forgive him Sir: and for his
Wrong to me, I will be before ye.
Durst his villainy extend to thee?
Nothing but heats of youth Sir.
Upon my life he sought my Bed.
I must confess he loved me:
Somewhat beyond a Son, and still pursued it
With such a Lust: I will not say Ambition,
That clean forgetting all obedience,
And only following his first heat unto me,
He hotly sought your death, and me in Marriage.
O Villain!
But I forget all: and am half ashamed
To press a man so far.
Where is the Duke? for Gods sake bring me to him.
Here I am; Each corner of the Dukedom
Sends new affrights forth: what wouldst thou speak?
I cannot Sir, my fear ties up my tongue.
Why, whats the matter? Take thy courage
To thee; and boldly speak, where are the Guard?
In the Gods name, cut with it:
Treason, treason.
In whom?
Double the Guard.
There is a fellow Sir.
Leave shaking man.
It is not for fear, but wonder.
There is a fellow Sir, close in the Lobby:
You of the Guard, look to the door there.
But let me know the business.
O that the hearts of men should be so hardened
Against so good a Duke, for Gods sake Sir,
Seek means to save yourself, This wretched slave
Has his sword in his hand, I know his heart:
O it hath almost killed me with the thought of it.
Where is he?

div.stage: Enter the Guard, and bring him in.

lg.l: The Lobby Sir, close in a corner:
Look to yourselves, for Heavens sake,
Methinks he is here already.
Fellows of the Guard be valiant.
Go sirs, and apprehend him; Treason shall
Never dare me in mine own Gates.

sp.speaker: Tim.

lg.l: It is done.

sp.stage: There they bring the Prince in.

lg.l: And thou shalt find it to thy best content.
Are these the comforts of my Age?
They are happy that end their days Contented
With a little, and live aloof from dangers, to a King
Every content doth a new; peril bring.
O let me live no longer, shame of Nature,
Bastard to Honour: Traitor, Murderer,
Devil in a human shape, Away with him,
He shall not breath his hot infection here.
Sir hear me.
Am I or he your Duke? away with him
To a close prison: your Highness now shall know,
Such branches must be cropped before they grow,
Whatever Fortune comes, I bid it welcome,
My innocency is my Armour: Gods preserve you.
Fare thee well. I shall never see so brave a Gentleman:
Would I could weep out his offences.
Or I would weep out mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Leon.

lg.l: Come Gentlemen, we will determine presently
About his death: we cannot be too forward in our
Safety: I am very sick, lead me unto my Bed.

sp.stage: Exeunt. Enter Cittizen and his Boye.

sp.speaker: Cittizen.
sp.p: Sirrah, go fetch my Fox from the Cutlers: There is money for the scouring: Tell him, I stop a Groat since the last great Muster: He had in store Pitch for the bruise. He took with the Recoiling of his Gun.

lg.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Cittiz.
sp.p: And do you hear? when you come, Take down my Buckler, and sweep the Cobwebs off: and Grind the pick out, and fetch a Nail or two: and Tack on bracers: your Mistress made a pot lid of it, I thank her at her Maids wedding, and burnt off the Handle.

lg.l: I will Sir.

sp.speaker: Cittiz.
sp.p: Who is within here, ho Neighbour, not stirring yet?

lg.l: O God morrow, god morrow: what
News, what news?
It holds, he dies this morning.
Then happy man be his fortune, I am resolved,
And so am I, and forty more good fellows
That will not give their heads for the washing, I take it.

sp.speaker: 2. Cittiz.
sp.p: 'sfoot man, who would not hang in such Good company, and such a cause? A Fire a Wife and Children, It is such a Jest that men should look behind em to the world: And let their honours, their honours Neighbour slip.

lg.l: I will give thee a pint of Bastard and a roll For that bare word,
They say that we Tailors, are things that
Lay one another, and our Geese hatch us: I will make some of them feele they are Geese at the game then,
Ifack take down my Bill, it is ten to one I use it, Take a
Good heart man, all the low ward is ours, with a wet
Finger.
And lay my Cut-fingered Gantlet ready for me,
That that I used to work in, when the Gentlemen: were
Up against us, a beaten out of town, and almost out a
Debt to, for a plague on them, they never paid well since,
And take heed sirrah: your mistress hears not of this
Business, she is near her time: yet if she do,
I care not, she may long for Rebellion,
For she has a devilish spirit,
Come, let us call up the new Ironmonger, is as
Tough as steel, and has a fine wit in these resurrections:
Are you stirring Neighbour?
O Good morrow Neighbours,
I will come to you presently.
Go to, this is his Mothers doing: she is a Polecat.
As any is in the world.

sp.p: Then say I have hit it, and a vengeance on her, let her be what she will.
Amen say I, she has brought things to a fine pass with her wisdom, do you mark it?

One thing I am sure she has, the good old Duke she gives him pap again they say, and dandles him, and hangs a coral and bells about his neck, and makes him believe his teeth will come again; which if they did, and I he, I would worry her as never cur was worried: I would neighbour till my teeth met I know where, but that is counsel.
Good morrow neighbours: hear you the sad news?

lg.l: Yes, would we knew as well how to prevent it.

sp.p: I cannot tell, methinks it were no great matter, if men were men: but —

lg.l: You do not twit me with my calling neighbour?

sp.p: No surely: for I know your spirit to be tall, pray be not vexed.

Pray forward with your counsel:
I am what I am, and they that prove me, shall find me to their cost: do you mark me neighbour, to their cost I say.

lg.l: Nay look how soon you are angry.
They shall neighbours: yes, I say they shall.
I do believe they shall.
I know they shall.
Whether you do or no I care not two-pence,
I am no beast, I know mine own strength neighbours;
God bless the King, your companies is fair.

sp.p: Nay neighbour now ye err, I must tell you so if ye were twenty neighbours,

lg.l: You had best go peach, do, peach.
Peach, I scorn the motion.

sp.p: Do, and see what follows: I will spend an hundred pound, and be two I care not, but I will undo thee.
Peach, o disgrace: peach in thy face, and do the worst thou canst: I am a true man, and a free-man peach!

lg.l: Nay look, you will spoil all.
Peach!

sp.p: Whilst you two brawl together, the Prince will lose his life.
Come, give me your hand, I love you well, are you for the action.

lg.l: Yes: but peach provokes me, it is a cold fruit,
I feele it cold in my stomach still.
No more, I will give you cake to digest it.

sp.p: Shut up my shop, and be ready at a call boys, and one of you run over my old tuck with a few ashes, it is grown odious with toasting cheese: and burn a little juniper in my murrain, the maid made it her chamber-pot, an hour hence I will come again; and as you hear from me, send me a clean shirt.

lg.l: The Chandler by the wharf, if it be thy will.
Gossip good morrow.

sp.p: O good morrow Gossip: good morrow all, I see we of one mind you cleave so close together: come it is time, I have prepared a hundred if they stand.

lg.l: It is well done: shall we sever, and about it?

sp.p: First let us to the Tavern, and a pint a piece will make us Dragons.

lg.l: I will have no mercy, come what will of it.

sp.p: If my tuck hold I will spit the Guard like Larks with sage between em.
I have a foolish bill to reckon with em, will make some of their hearts ache, and I will lay it on: now shall I fight, it will do you good to see me.
Come I will do something for the Town to talk of when I am rotten: pray God there be enough to kill, that is all.

lg.l: How black the day begins!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Can you blame it, and look upon such a deed as shall be done this morning?

lg.l: Does the Prince suffer today?
Within this hour they say.

sp.speaker: Agen.
sp.p: Well, they that are most wicked are most safe: it will be a strange Justice and a lamentable, gods keep us from the too soon feeling of it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I care not if my throat were next: for to live still, and live here, were but to grow fat for the Shambles.

sp.speaker: Nis.
sp.p: Yet we must do it, and thank em too, that our lives may be accepted.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Faith I will go starve myself, or grow diseased to shame the hangman; for I am sure he shall be my Herald, and quarter me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Aye a plague on him, he is too excellent at arms.

sp.speaker: Nisus.
sp.p: Will you go see this sad sight my Lord Agenor?

lg.l: I will make a mourner.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: If I could do him any good I would go, The bare sight else will but afflict my spirit, my prayers shall be as near him as your eyes: As you find him settled, remember my love and service to his Grace.

lg.l: We will weep for joy sir, farewell.
Farewell to all our happiness, a long farewell.
Thou angry power, whether of heaven or hell,
That layest this sharpe correction on our Kingdom
For our offences, infinite and mighty,
O hear me, and at length be pleased, be pleased
With pity to draw back thy vengeance,
Too heavy for our weakness; and accept,
(Since it is your discretion, heavenly Wisdoms,
To have it so) this sacrifice for all,
That now is flying to your happiness,
Only for you most fit: let all our sins suffer in him.
Gods, whats the matter! I hope it is joy.
How now my Lords?
I will tell you with that little breath I have;
More joy than you dare think, The Prince is safe from
Danger.
How!
It is true, and thus it was; His hour was come
To lose his life, he ready for the stroke,
Nobly, and full of Saint-like patience,
Went with his Guard: which when the people saw,
Compassion first went out, mingled with tears,
That bred desires, and whispers to each other,
To do some worthy kindness for the Prince.
And ere they understood well how to do,
Fury stepped in, and taught them what to do,
Thrusting on every hand to rescue him,
As a white innocent: then flew the roar
Through all the streets, of Save him, save him, save him;
And as they cried, they did for catching up
Such sudden weapons as their madness show them.
In short, they beat the Guard, and took him from em,
And now march with him like a royal Army.
Heaven, heaven I thank thee,
What a slave was I to have my hand so far from
This brave rescue, it had been a thing to brag on
When I was old. Shall we run for a wager to the
Next Temple and give thanks?

sp.speaker: Nis.

lg.l: As fast as wishes.

sp.stage: Enter Leucippus and Ismenus: the people within stoppes.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Good friends go home again, there is not a man shall go with me.

lg.l: Will you not take revenge? I will call them on.
All that love me depart:
I thank you, and will serve you for your loves:
But I will thank you more to suffer me
To govern em once: more, I do beg ye,
For my sake to your houses.
Gods preserve you.
And what house will you go to?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Ismenus I will take the wariest courses that I can think of to defend myself, but not offend.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: You may kill your mother, and never offend your father an honest man.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Thou knowest I can scape now, that is all I look for: I will leave.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p:
Tima. a pox take him, would I had him here, I would kill him at his own weapon single sith we
have built enough on him: plague on it, I am out of all patience: discharge such an Army as this, that would have followed you without paying, o gods!

lg.l: To what end should keep em? I am free.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: Yes, free of the Traitors, for you are proclaimed one.

lg.l: Should I therefore make myself one?
This is one of your moral Philosophy is it?
Heaven bless me from subtleties to undo myself with;
But I know if, reason herself were here,
She would not part with her own safety.
Well, pardon Ismenus, for I know
My courses are most just; nor will I stain em
With one bad action: for thyself, thou knowest,
That though I may command thee, I shall be
A ready servant to thee if thou needst: and so I will
Take my leave.
of whom?
Of thee.
Heart, you shall take no leave of me.
Shall I not?

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: No by the gods shall you not: nay if you have no more wit but to go absolutely alone, I will be in a little.

lg.l: Nay prithee good Ismenus part with me.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: I will not i'faith, never move it any more; for by this good light I will not.

lg.l: This is an ill time to be thus unruly:
Ismenus you must leave me.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Yes if you can beat me away: else, the gods refuse me if I will leave you till I see more reason; you shall not undo yourself.

lg.l: But why wilt not leave me?

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p:
Why I will tell you, Because when you are gone, then — life, if I have not forgot my reason— hell take me: you put me out of patience so: O!
marry when you are gone, then will your Mother: a pox confound her, she never comes in my head but she spoils my memory too: there are a hundred reasons.

lg.l: But show me one.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Show you, what a stir here is, why I will show you: Do you think; well, well, I know what I know, I pray come, come. It is in vain: but I am sure. Devils take em, what do I meddle with em? You know yourself. Soul, I think I am: is there any man in the world? as if you knew not this already better than I. Pish, pish, I will give no reason.

lg.l: But I will tell thee one why thou shouldst stay:
I have not one friend in the Court but thou,
On whom I may be bold to trust to send me
Any intelligence: and if thou lovest me
Thou wilt do this, thou needst not fear to stay,
For there are new-come Proclamations out;
Where all are pardoned but myself.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: It is true, and in the same Proclamation your fine sister Vrania, whom you used so kindly, is proclaimed heir apparent to the Crown.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: What though, thou mayst stay at home without danger.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Danger, hang danger, what tell you me of danger?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Why if thou wilt not do it, I think thou darest not.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: I dare not: if you speak it in earnest, you are a boy.

lg.l: Well fir, if you dare, let me see you do it.
Why so you shall, I will stay.
Why God a mercy.
You know I love you but too well.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Now take these few directions: farewell, send to me by the wariest ways thou canst: I have a soul tells me we shall meet often. The gods protect thee.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Pox o'me on myself for an Ass, I am crying now, God be with you, if I never see you again: why then pray get you gone, for grief and anger will not let me know what I say. I will to the Court as fast as I can, and see the new heir apparent.

lg.l: What hast thou found him?
Madam he is coming in.
Gods bless my brother wheresoever he is:
And I beseech you keep me from the bed
Of any naughty Tyrant whom my mother
Would have me have to wrong him.
What would her new Grace have with me?
Leave us a while. My Lord Ismenus,
I pray for the love of heaven and God,
That you would tell me one thing, which I know
You can do well.
Wheres her sain Grace?
You know me well enough, but that you mock,
I am she my sen.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: God bless him that shall be thy husband, if thou wearest breeches thus soon, thou wilt be as impudent as thy mother.

lg.l: But will you tell me this one thing?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: What is it? if it be no great matter whether I do or no, perhaps I will.

lg.l: Yes faith it is matter.
And what is it?
I pray you let me know where the Prince my brother is.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I'faith you shall be hanged first, is your mother so foolish to think your good Grace can sift it out of me?

sp.speaker: Vrania.
sp.p: If you have any mercy left in you to a poor wench tell me.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Why wouldst not thou have thy brains beat out for this, to follow thy mothers steps so young?

lg.l: But believe me, she knows none of this.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Believe you? why do you think I never had wits? or that I am run out of them? how should it belong to you to know, If I could tell?

lg.l: Why I will tell you: and if I speak false
Let the Devil have me, Yonder is a bad man,
Come from a Tyrant to my mother, and what name
They have for him, good faith I cannot tell.
An Ambassador.
That is it: but he would carry me away,
And have me marry his Master; and I will die
Ere I will have him.
But whats this to knowing where the Prince is?
Yes, for you know all my mother does:
Against the Prince is but to make me great.
Pray, I know that too well, what ten?
Why I would go to the good Marquess my
Brother, and put myself into his hands, that so
He may preserve himself.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: O that thou hadst no seed of thy Mother in thee, and couldst mean this now.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: Why faith I do, would I might never stir more if I do not.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I shall prove a ridiculous fool, I will be damned else: hang me if I do not half believe thee.

lg.l: By my troth you may.
By my troth I do: I know I am an Ass for it,
But I cannot help it.
And will you tell me then?
Yes faith will I, or anything else in the world, for
I think thou art as good a creature as ever was born.
But I will go in this latest apparel:
But you mun help me to Silver.

sp.speaker: Ismenus.

lg.l: Why, if I do, would I might never see day again.
Nay by this light I do not think thou wilt:
I will presently provide thee money and a letter.

sp.speaker: Ura.

lg.l: Aye but I will never deliver it.
When I have found my Brother, I will beg
To serve him; but he shall never know who I am;
For he must hate me then for my bad mother:
I will say I am a country Lad that want a service,
And have strayed on him by chance, lest he discover me;
I know I must not live long, but that time
I have to spend, shall be in serving him.
And though my Mother seek to take his life away,
In a day my brother shall be taught that I was
Ever good, though she were naught.

sp.stage: Enter Bacha and Timantus: Bacha reading a Letter.

lg.l: Run away, the devil be her guide.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Faith she is gone: there is a Letter I found it in her pocket, would I were with her, she is a handsome Lady, a plague upon my bashfulness, I had bobbed her long ago else.

lg.l: What a base Whore is this, that after all
My ways for her advancement, should so poorly make virtue her undoer, and choose this time,
The King being deadly sick: and I intending
A present marriage with some foreign Prince,
To strengthen and secure myself. She writes here
Like a wise Gentle woman; She will not stay:
And the example of her dear brother, makes her
Fear herself, to whom she means to fly.
Why, who can help it?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Now poverty and Lechery which is thy end, rot thee, wherever to goest with all thy goodness.

sp.speaker: Timan.
sp.p: Byrlady they will bruise her: if she wear a brass. I am sure they will break stone walls: I have had experience of them both, and they have made me desperate: but there is a Messenger Madam come from the Prince with a Letter to Ismenus, who by him returns an answer.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: This comes as pat as wishes: thou shalt presently away Timantus.

lg.l: Whither Madam?
To the Prince, and take the Messenger for guide.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What shall I do there? I have done too much mischief to be believed again, or indeed, to scape with my head on my back if I be once known.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Thou art a weak shallow fool: get thee a disguise, and withal, when thou comest before him, have a Letter feigned to deliver him; and then, as thou hast ever hope of goodness by me, or after me, strike one home stroke that shall not need another: darest thou speak, darest thou? if thou fallest off, go be a Rogue a again, and lie and Pander to procure thy meat: darest thou speak to me.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sure I shall never walk when I am dead. I have no spirit Madam, I will be drunk but I will do it, that is all my refuge.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Away, no more, then I will raise an Army whilst the King yet lives, if all the means and power I have can do it I cannot tell.

lg.l: Are you inventing still? we will ease your studies.
Why how now saucy Lords?
Nay I will shake ye, yes devil, I will shake ye.
Do not you know me Lords?
Yes deadly sin we know ye, would we did not.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Do you hear Whore, a plague of God upon thee, the Duke is dead.

lg.l: Dead!

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Aye, wild-fire and brimstone take thee: good man he is dead, and past those miseries which thou, salt infection-like, like a disease, flungest upon his head. Dost thou hear, and it were not more respect in Woman-hood in general than thee, because I had a Mother, who I will not say she was good, she lived so near thy time, I would have thee in vengeance of this man, whose peace is made in heaven by this time, tide to a post, and dried in the sun, and after carried about and shone at fairs for money, with a long story of the devil thy father that taught thee to be whorish, envious, bloody.

lg.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: You fleering harlot, I will have a horse to leap thee, and thy base issue shall carry Sumpters. Come Lords, bring her along, we will to the Prince all, where her hell-hood shall wait his censure; and if he spare thee she Goat, may he lie with thee again; and beside, mayst thou upon him some nasty soul disease that hate still follows, and his end, a dry ditch. Lead you corrupted whore, or I will draw goad shall make you skip: away to the Prince.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I hope yet I shall come too late to find him.
sp.stage: Enter Loucippus, Vrana,: Leu, with a bloudy handkercher.

lg.l: Alas poor boy, why dost thou follow me?
What canst thou hope for? I am poor as thou art.
In good faith I shall be well and rich enough
If you will love me, and not put me from you.
Why dost thou choose out me boy to undo thee?
Alas, for pity take another Master,
That may be able to deserve thy love
In breeding thee hereafter: me thou knowest not
More than my misery: and therefore canst not
Look for rewards at my hands: would I were able,
My pretty knave, to do thee any kindness: truly
Good boy, I would upon my faith thy harmlessly
Innocence moves me at heart, wilt thou go
Save thyself, why doest thou weep? Alas I do not chide thee.

sp.speaker: Urania.
sp.p: I cannot tell if I go from you, Sir I shall never dawn day more: Pray if you can I will be true To you: Let me wait on you: If I were a man, I would fight for you: Sure you have some ill-willers, I would slay them.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Such harmless souls are ever Prophets, well I take thy wish, thou shalt be with me still: But prithee eat, then my good Boy: Thou wilt die my child If thou fasts one day more. This four days thou hast tasted nothing: Go into the Cave and eat: Thou shalt find something for thee, to bring thy blood again, and thy fair colour.

lg.l: I cannot eat God thank you,
But I will eat tomorrow.
Thou wilt be dead by that time.
I should be well then, for you will not love me.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Indeed I will. This is the prettiest passion that ere I felt yet: why dost you look so earnestly upon me?

lg.l: You have fair eyes Master.
Sure the Boy dotes: why dost thou sigh my child?

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: To think that such a fine man should live, and no gay Lady love him.

lg.l: Thou wilt love me?

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: Yes sure till I die, and when I am in heaven I will even wish for you.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: And I will come to thee Boy. This is a love I never yet heard tell of: come, thou art sleepy child, go in; and I will sit with thee: heaven what portends this?

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: You are sad, but I am not sleepy, would I could do aught to make you merry: shall I sing?

lg.l: If thou wilt good Boy.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Alas my boy, that thou shouldst comfort me, and art far worse than I:
sp.stage: Enter Timantus with a letter disguised.

lg.l: Law Master, there is one, look to your sen.
What art thou, that in this dismal place,
Which nothing could find out but misery,
Thus boldly stepped? Comfort was never here,
Here is nor food, nor beds, nor any house
Built by a better Architect than beasts;
And ere you get dwelling from one of them,
You must fight for it: if you conquer him,
He is your meat; if not, you must be his.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I come to you (for if I not mistake, you are the Prince) from that most Noble Lord Ismenus with a Letter.

lg.l: Alas, I fear I shall be discovered now.

sp.speaker: Leu.

lg.l: Now I feele myself the poorest of all mortal things.
Where is he that receives such courtesies,
But he has means to show his gratefulness
Some way or other? I have none at all:
I know not how to speak so much as well
Of thee but to these trees.

sp.stage: Leucippus opening the Letter, the whilst Timantus runne at him, and Vrania steppes before.

lg.l: His Letters speak him sir —

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: Gods keep me but from knowing him till I die: aye me, sure I cannot live a day, o thou foul Traitor: How do you Master?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: How dost thou my child? alas, look on his, it may make thee repentant, to behold those innocent drops that thou hast drawn from thence.

lg.l: It is nothing sir and you be well.
O pardon me, know you me now sir?
How couldst thou find me out?

sp.speaker: Tima.
sp.p:
We intercepted a Letter from Ismenus, and
the bearer directed me.

lg.l: Stand up Timantus boldly,
The world conceives that thou art guilty
Of divers treasons to the State and me:
But o far be it from the innocence
Of a just man to give a traitor death
Without a trial: here thy Country is not
To purge thee or condemn thee; therefore
A nobler trial than thou dost deserve,
Rather than none at all, here I accuse thee
Before the face of heaven, to be a traitor
Both to the Duke my father and to me, and the
Whole Land: speak, is it so or no?
It is true sir, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Take heed Timantus how thou dost cast away thyself, I must proceed to execution hastily if thou confess it: speak once again, is it so or no?

sp.speaker: Tim.

lg.l: I am not guilty sir.

sp.stage: Fight here: the Prince gets his sword and giues it him.

lg.l: Gods and thy sword acquit thee, here it is.
I will not use any violence against your Highness.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: At thy peril then, for this must be thy trial: and from hence forth look to thyself.
sp.stage: Timantus drawes his sword, and runnes at him when he turnes aside.

lg.l: I do beseech you sir let me not fight.
Up, up again Timantus,
There is no way but this believe me.
Now if — Fie, fie Timantus, is there no
Usage can recover thee from baseness? wert thou
Longer to converse with men, I would have chid
Thee for this: be all thy faults forgiven.
O spare me sir, I am not fit for death.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p:
I think thou art not; yet trust me, fitter than
for life: Yet tell me ere my breath be gone, knowest of any other plots against me?

lg.l: Of none.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: What course wouldst thou have taken when thou hadst killed me?

lg.l: I would have taken your Page, and married her.
What Page?
Your boy there. —
Is he fallen mad in death, what does he mean?
Some good God help me at the worst: how dost thou?
Let not thy misery vex me, thou shalt have
What thy poor heart can wish: I am a Prince.
And I will keep thee in the gayest clothes,
And the finest things, that ever pretty boy had given him.
I know you well enough,
Faith I am dying, and now you know all too.
But stir up thyself; look what a Jewel here is,
See how it glisters: what a pretty show
Will this make in thy little ear? ha, speak,
Eat but a bit, and take it.
Do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I prithee mind thy health: why that is well said my good boy, smile still.

lg.l: I shall smile till death if I see you.
I am Vrania your sister-in-law.
How!
I am Vrania.
Dullness did seize me, now I know thee well;
Alas why camest thou hither?

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: Faith for love, I would not let you know till I was dying; for you could not love me, my Mother was so naught.

lg.l: I will love thee, or anything: what? wilt
Thou leave me as soon as I know thee?
Speak one word to me: alas she is past it,
She will never speak more.
What noise is that? it is no matter who
Comes on me now. What worse than mad are you
That seek out sorrows? if you love delights
Be gone from hence.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Sir, for you we come, as Soldiers to revenge the wrongs you have suffered under this naughty Creature: what shall be done with her? say, I am ready.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Leave her to heaven brave Cousin, they shall tell her how she has sinned against em, my hand shall never be stained with such base blood: live wicked Mother, that reverent title be your pardon, for I will use no extremity against you, but leave you to heaven.

lg.l: Hell take you all, if there be a place
Of torment that exceeds that, get you thither:
And till the devils have you, may your lives
Be one continued plague, and such a one,
That knows no friends nor ending.
May all ages that shall succeed curse you as I do:
And if it be possible, I ask it heaven,
That your base issues may be ever Monsters,
That must for shame of nature and succession,
Be drowned like dogs
Would I had breath to please you.
Would you had love within you, and such
Grief as might become a Mother: look you there,
Know you that face, that was Vrania:
These are the fruits of those unhappy Mothers,
That labour with such horrid births as you do:
If you can weep, there is cause; poor innocent,
Your wickedness has killed her: I will weep for you.
Monstrous woman,
Mars would weep at this, and yet she cannot.
Here lies your Minion too, slain by my hand,
I will not say you are the cause: yet certain,
I know you were to blame, the Gods forgive you.
See, she stands as if she were inventing
Some new destruction for the world.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Ismenus, thou art welcome yet to my sad company.

lg.l: I come to make you somewhat sadder sir.
You cannot, I am at the height already.
Your Fathers dead.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I thought so, heaven be with him: o woman, woman, weep now or never, thou hast made more sorrows than we have eyes to utter.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Now let heaven fall, I am at the worst of evils, a thing so miserable wretched, that everything, the last of human comforts hath left me: I will not be so base and cold, to live and wait the mercies of these men I hate: no, it is just I die, since Fortune hath left me my step descent attends me: hand, strike thou home, I have soul enough to guide; and let all know, as I stood a Queen, the same I will fall, and one with me.
sp.stage: She stabs the Prince with a knife.

lg.l: Ho.
How do you sir?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Nearer my health, than I think any here, my tongue begins to falter: what is man? or who would be one, when he sees a poor weak woman can in an instant make him none.

lg.l: She is dead already.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Let her be damned already as she is: post all for Sergeants.

lg.l: Let not a man stir, for I am but dead:
I have some few words which I wold have you hear,
And am afraid I shall want breath to speak em:
First to you my Lords, You know Ismenus is
Undoubtedly heir of Licia, I do beseech you all,
When I am dead to show your duties to him.
We vow to do it.
I thank you.
Next to you Cousin Ismenus, that shall be the Duke,
I pray you let the broken Image of Cupid
Be re-edified, I know all this is done by him.
It shall be so.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Last, I beseech you that my Mother-in-Law may have a burial according to —

lg.l: To what sir?
There is a full point.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I will interpret for him; she shall have burial according to her own deserts, with dogs.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I would your Majesty would haste for settling of the people.

lg.l: I am ready.
Agenor, go and let the Trumpets sound
Some mournful thing, whilst we convey the body
Of this unhappy Prince unto the Court,
And of that virtuous Virgin to a grave:
But drag her to a ditch, where let her lie
Accursed, whilst one man has a memory.
The time now of my Revenge draws near;
Nor shall it lessen, as I am a god,
With all the cries and prayers that have been;
And those that be to come, though they be infinite,
In need and number.
